Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC) wrote:

> 	Can't break!!?? You never make typos and return the wrong variable
> in a getter, or set the wrong variable in a setter? If so, you're a better
> coder than me :)

I got bit by exactly that recently... i didn't test a setter-getter i 
had written. And i *cut and pasted* it from another setter-getter pair 
with the same return type.

A while later, i had to resort to printf() to debug some other, 
relatively simple code that kept failing its unit test. Of course, it 
was reading the wrong value out of the getter. Sure, it didn't take THAT 
long to debug, but it certainly took an order of magnitude more time 
than the minute or two it would have required to write and run a 
setter-getter unit test. And it broke my rhythm, as last-resort 
debugging is prone to do.

Which reminds me of another thing i've found i like about JUnit... when 
i do printf() debugging now, i almost always do it in the unit tests 
rather than the code itself. With more complex classes, i sometimes 
define toString() to dump the object's internal state, so i can just 
print out objects from JUnit tests. This is way better than the piles of 
printf() statements that used to litter my code.

--
